name: persea-palustris
wildlife-value: This plant is a larval host for Spicebush Swallowtail and Palamedes Swallowtail. The fruit is eaten by birds and small mammals.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Dark blue fruit on hairy reddish stalks from September to October.
flower-description: Small, light yellow-green flowers occurring in small clusters in leaf axils from May to June.
leaf-description: 2-8 inch long and 1-2 inch wide green leaves are lanceolate with entire margins. Upper surface is dark green and shiny, undersides is a silvery-white color with an orange tinge from pubescence that occurs primarily along the midvein.
bark-description: The bark ranges from red to grayish-brown with irregular furrows with flat-topped ridges, quite thick.
uses: Native Americans used the plant medicinally.
